abstracts.cdata!:
The ratings for the Science and
            Technology Reform Support Project for Brazil were as
            follows: the outcome was satisfactory, the sustainability
            was likely, the institutional development impact was
            substantial, and the Bank and borrower performance were both
            satisfactory. The lessons learned indicate that
            Public-private partnerships in the Technology Development
            Component proved to be a highly effective mechanism to
            benefit the Brazilian Science and Technology (S&T)
            market. Private funding and partnership commitment secured
            technology transfer in most cases. Competitive funding in
            both the Technology Development and the Science and
            Technology Research Components was an important factor in
            the level of commitment and the quality of output generated.
            Complexity in project design is exacerbated during times of
            crisis, and may de facto create blocks of consolidation
            around critical core functions and programs. In order for
            Brazil to become fully competitive with other advanced
            countries in terms of science, technology and innovation, it
            would be necessary to further improve the Ministry of
            Science and Technology (MCT's) capacity for policy
            formulation. Brazil faces two gaps - the external gap with
            the more advanced economies and the internal gaps between
            individual states in the country.
